Subject: Re: [neat] What is the most recommended action selection policy for NEAT?
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=344770077; y=9I6z9sb1w_BtVAN6hio9zxUHvaE_DTwIGvqxtN3kbGJlvMDXfQ6n
X-Yahoo-Profile: alienseedpod
From: Colin Green <colin.green1@...>

On 7 November 2017 at 10:18, milind.dalvi14@... [neat]
<neat@yahoogroups.com> wrote:
>
> Upon investigating C# SharpNEAT examples I found various domains use
>
> action = output_signal_array[0] > 0.5 (for binary classification) as found
> in single pole balancing example

[...]

> And what's with the comparison with 0.5? Is it because 0.5 is mean of
> sigmoid activation output?

Well yeh it's the mid or central point of the sigmoid, so we're just
saying any activation level above the mid point is 'active' and any
below is 'inactive'.

Note however that the more recent box2d based pole balancing task
utilises the full continuous range of the output instead of
simplifying it to an on/off action:

 https://github.com/colgreen/sharpneat/blob/master/src/SharpNeatDomainsExtra/SinglePoleBalancingBox2d/SinglePoleBalancingBox2dEvaluator.cs#L111


> Given an output signal array from NEAT network, what is the best recommended
> action selection policy for deciding which action to take in any
> classification domain?

There's probably some justification for using Softmax over the various
methods you found used in sharpneat. Softmax is a generalisation of
the logistic sigmoid to N states rather than two states. You can think
of it as a method for normalising unbounded signals (the output node
values before going through a sigmoid) such that they sum to one, i.e.
can be interpreted as probabilities of N classes/categories.

The code you're seeing in, e.g. the sharpneat prey capture code is my
initial/naive attempt at defining an output layer scheme that can
produce four action outputs (move up/down/left/right). That code is
nearly 20 years old - if I were writing it now I'd probably use
softmax. I guess I should try softmax and update the code if it works
well.



> or, use n+1 nodes for n action selection like prey capture example
> or, maybe selecting the action based on maximum value

Not sure why you said n+1(?) It's just n nodes for n
classes/categories/actions, right?


>
> var action = output_signal_array.IndexOf(output_signal_array.Max());
>

You could do that *after* normalisation with softmax; I figure that's
how you'd use softmax, unless you wanted to stochastically select from
the normalised probabilities; both of those approaches are reasonable
but would require some investigation to see how well they work in
practice.



> Also unlike Q-learning practice where action selection policy has direct
> effect on explore-exploit dilemma, is NEAT's explore-exploit dilemma
> affected with which policy we choose?
>

Sorry, I don't understand this question.


Colin.
